Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge erred in concluding the applicant did not meet the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant provided evidence of 1,097 days of physical presence in Canada within the four years preceding the application
Remedy_Requested: Allowance of appeal and referral for redetermination
Court_Ruling: Appeal allowed; case referred to a different citizenship judge
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship judge applied two qualitative tests simultaneously and disregarded passport evidence without justification
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper application of residency tests and failure to properly assess documentary evidence
Legal_Standard: Applicant must prove physical presence in Canada for at least 1,095 days within four years prior to application
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence duration, credibility of travel records, validity of passport evidence
Applicable_Legislation: Citizenship Act, subsection 14(5); Federal Courts Act, section 21
Procedural_Issue: Appeal process initiated under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Review_Standard: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by appellate review of administrative decision)
Credibility_Assessment: Passport evidence was credible but improperly dismissed
Evidence_Used: Passport records showing entry and exit dates, applicant's sworn statements
Legal_Provision_Cited: Citizenship Act, paragraph 5(1)(c), subsection 14(5); Federal Courts Act, section 21
Application_Basis: Request for Canadian citizenship based on residency eligibility
Evidence_Assessed: Documentary proof of days physically present in Canada
Relief_Sought: Reassessment of citizenship application by an unbiased citizenship judge
Governing_Rule: 1,095 days of physical presence required; qualitative tests cannot override statutory requirement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found in applicant’s submission; deficiency alleged by judge not substantiated
Outcome: Appeal allowed, case remitted for redetermination
Harm_Assessment: Unjust denial of citizenship due to legal error in residency assessment
Cause_Description: Denial of citizenship application based on alleged failure to meet residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Passport evidence was disregarded without adequate justification
Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act (as alleged, but ultimately not proven)
Evidence_Issues: Failure to account for valid passport documentation supporting residency
Evidence_Assessment: Passport evidence sufficient to establish physical presence
Decision_Rationale: Judge erred by combining qualitative tests with quantitative requirement and dismissing key evidence without basis
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of justification for rejecting passport evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective measurement of physical presence supported by reliable documentation
